**M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**, child custody orders may be modified where there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the child.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.raw_text: *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 421 N.E.2d 521 (1981).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**, child custody orders may be modified where there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standards for an initial custody determination in a divorce action, focusing on the best interests of the child and parental fitness. It does not involve or analyze a request to modify an existing custody order, nor does it mention or apply M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 or the “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition about modification of custody orders under § 28.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Courts have consistently recognized that the safety, stability, and emotional well-being of the child are paramount considerations in determining a child’s best interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that the governing standard under the removal statute is the “best interests of the child” and explains that this requires attention to the child’s quality of life and the impact of the move on the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs. The court explicitly notes that in removal cases “the effect on the child of any removal is most important” and that the best-interests inquiry focuses on how the child’s life may be improved or harmed, showing that the child’s safety, stability, and emotional well-being are paramount considerations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 181,.proposition: Courts have consistently recognized that the safety, stability, and emotional well-being of the child are paramount considerations in determining a child’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 181,.support_reasoning: The opinion applies and describes the “best interests of the child” standard in a removal/relocation context and evaluates factors like the child’s educational and social development, emotional harm from parental conflict, and the importance of maintaining relationships with both parents. While the court does not use the exact phrasing that safety, stability, and emotional well-being are ‘paramount,’ its analysis clearly treats those aspects of the child’s welfare as central to the best-interests determination, which is consistent with the claimed proposition.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 181,.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’… Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’… [T]he judge’s findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, [and] that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests… [show] that removal is not in the children’s best interests.”}

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 841, 7.proposition: When a parent’s physical impairment impacts their ability to care for a child’s daily needs and safety, modification is warranted to protect the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 841, 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address modification of an existing custody order due to a parent’s physical impairment, nor does it discuss a parent whose physical condition compromises the child’s daily care or safety. Instead, the case applies the general “best interests of the child” standard and statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) in an original custody determination between two fit parents. There is no holding or reasoning that a change in custody is warranted when a parent’s physical impairment affects caregiving ability, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 841, 7.relevant_excerpt: “The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.… In most cases, however, if the child has been living with one parent for some time, the child’s needs are being adequately met under that parent’s care, and that parent is capable of continuing to care for the child, it is not in the child’s best interests to disrupt that successful arrangement.”
